Message.Title: Where are the downgrades and lowered price targets?
Message.Msg: Earnings and revenue estimates are being slahed. The only reason for the optimism last Q after terrible release was that gross margin (revenue less Cost of sales and fulfillment) went from 14.6% to 15.5% .. this pushed many analysts to think AMZN could get to 4% net margin some day. Well guess what, in Q3 GM dropped to 14.3% - even less than Q1 !!! Lets see - growth has slowed, margins are declining, R&D spending is inccreasing at a breakneck pace to produce products they are losing money on, looking at piles of depreciation and new employees they don't need .... wow a P/E of 20 sounds about right on $2 earning next year ... $40. just a matter of time before big money has to throw in the towel.

Message.Msg: THIS IS YOUR SCAMAZON FRAUD IN USA: HANG $UCKING FRAUD STREET BANKSTERS/SE.C. CRIMINALS IN A PUBLIC SQUARE By singhlion2001 . Oct 25, 2012 9:15 PM . Permalink THEY ARE RAPING USA 99% WORKING CLASS PENSIONS TO BECOME BILLIONAIRES AND DESTROYING RETAIL JOBS IN USA In the international segment, revenue grew 22% to 5.51 billion adjusting for the $269 million year-over-year unfavorable foreign exchange impact, revenue growth was 28%. Media revenue grew 8% to 2.25 billion or 12% excluding foreign exchange. And EGM revenue grew 34% to 3.22 billion or 42% excluding foreign exchange. EGM now represents 59% of international revenues up from 53%. International segment operating income decreased 91% to 16 million or 0.3% operating margin. Excluding the unfavorable impact from foreign exchange, international segment operating income decreased 74%. Consolidated segment operating income decreased 7% to 360 million or 2.8% of revenue down approximately 109 basis points year-over-year. Excluding the unfavorable impact from foreign exchange CSOI decreased 4%. Unlike CSOI, our GAAP operating income includes stock based compensation expense and other operating expense. GAAP operating income decreased 47% to $107 million or 0.8% of net sales. Our income tax expense was $109 million a 75% effective tax rate for the quarter and includes a one-time expense of $51 million related to the integration of Kiva Systems acquisition. Accordingly, our Q2 2012 effective tax rate is higher than both our current estimated 2012 annual effective rate and our 2011 effective tax rate. GAAP net income was $7 million or $0.01 per diluted share compared with $191 million and $0.41 per diluted share. Q2 2012 net income includes $65 million of estimated loss related to the acquisition and integration of Kiva Systems. Turning to the balance sheet. Cash and marketable securities decreased 1.39 billion year-over-year to 4.97 billion. Inventory increased 36% to 4.3 billion and inventory turns were 10.1 down from 11.3 turns a year ago as we expanded selection, improved in stock levels and introduced new product categories. Accounts payable increased 24% to 7.07 billion and accounts payable days decreased to 68 from 69 in the prior year. Our Q2 2012 capital expenditures were $657 million, the increase in capital expenditures reflects additional investments in support of continued business growth consisting of investments in technology infrastructure including Amazon web services and additional capacity to support our funding operations. Sentiment: Strong Sell

Topic.Title: Buy weekly puts at open?

Message.Msg: That is gambling. Buy LT puts and far fewer than you can afford -- reserve cash for it to move against you. Then, when it is extended, load up at a discount. No need to watch the exponential decay kick in and wipe out your account. Learn to beat these aholes at their game. PJ can testify, the strategy works. It's judo. But, you have to stay LT where the exponential decay does not kick in...

Message.Title: Jefferies maintains $300 price target
Message.Msg: "Jefferies noted that Amazon’s third quarter marked the fourth straight quarter that their operating income exceeded the high end of guidance." The positive reaction to higher-than-guidance operating margins might make sense IF the stock had first gone down when greatly reduced Q3 guidance was issued along with Q2 report. By this logic company could continue to issue lower guidance and then beating it all the way to bankruptcy. I also note that there is very little discussion of gross margin this Q, which was such a big deal last quarter when it moved to new highs - despite the fact that every 10Q reiterates that operating margins are a better measure of success. BTW gross margins were down from Q2.

Topic.Title: Why are calls and puts both down huge? Anyone?

Message.Msg: Part of an options price is volatility, which is always very high prior to earnings. You'll see this most in the nearest term options, like those expiring today. The $220 puts expiring today were $5 or $6 at this price yesterday. Now they are $0.10. Some of that is the theta decay. Most is the volatility.

Message.Title: Stock price is not indicative of underlying corporation
Message.Msg: Everybody seems to be fixated on the idea that the stock price has to relate the corporation with the same name. Not at all. The stock price is nothing more than a gamble. It is akin to poker. Nobody knows what the other person is holding. And a pair may be high or low. The bet is not on the card but on what the other person will do with their hand. The game is of investing is nothing more than a way to get somebody else's money. It is a simple bet with the hope you win. And the more times you win the more money you took from other players. And good for you. If you keep losing then you are not a good gambler.

Topic.Title: How do momo bots hold the price up AND sell it with flash crash phat phingured trading speed?

Message.Msg: Short this stock now. LOL seriously though, I (and MANY others) only have a vague idea as to what you're talking about.... we couldn't possibly answer that seriously. However, my best guess is that they are indeed NOT playing together, but the way that they are playing the game is still beneficial to each other. There are many many large holders trying to dump right now, and each is big enough to influence stock price on their own. So they don't simply dump, they use trading algorithms to keep the price up as high as possible so that THEY can sell their shares for as much as possible. None of them are trying to break this stock as they are holding so much, they are simply attempting to get as much value out of the shares that they currently own. This can certainly give the appearance of them playing together, when in fact they are not - their self serving strategies are simply mutually beneficial. As far as exactly how do you dump 10 million shares without bringing the stock down? I have no idea, I have never found myself in this fortunate position :P What do you think?

I never buy under 2 peg unless i'm buying dividend. amzn is a market leader but these valuations are out of control. they're not without competition. sales tax now a factor... big box stores are matching online prices (ie, best buy)... ipad mini... facebook gifts.. the list goes on. amzn has no margins! where's the barrier to entry beyond amzn's scale?? To justify these rediculous valuations, they need absolute perfection in the face of competion from ebay, apple, overstock etc. Even with perfection, I see catch 22 for amzn... they can't expand margins and maintain sales growth. They will be lucky if sales don't collapse when the company attempts to switch gears.

Message.Title: AMZN Trading Action
Message.Msg: Today's trading action in AMZN was complete, in your face, beyond obvious, exhibit of what is wrong with Wall Street ethics, high speed frequency trading and the manipulation of a stock price. They say manipulation does not exist, but it does and today was the biggest example of it that I have ever seen. What is manipulation and how does it happen? Insider trading is definitely one. But there are other more disguised methods, and I believe that is what is at work right now. There is a deliberate movement to run this stock higher NO MATTER what the company does to steal/thieve money from others who are using the company's actual performance to make their stock or option decisions. The company's conference call was a joke. It's is being mentioned across the media. It is being written about by many. The trading action was a BLATANT disregard of a company that is not growing anything but it's expenses, it has begun to lose money, and it is a mature company (over 13 years old). The likes of MSFT (a mature company no longer to offer "growth"), AAPl, growth COULD slow, even though they make TONS of money...these stocks are sold off hard for excellent performance and execution. Yet Bezos mumbles a bunch of stuff that is basically worthless, guides lower, the stock rips to gouge those put writers, or short sellers, who are taking positions based on the criteria that governs all other companies. Something is clearly awry here, and it's the stuff of EVIL. If this does not trigger some form of investigation into Amazon and Bezo's Wall Street connections/relationshps..then I don't know what will. For those of you that agree, what we can do is huge. Not only can we make calls and get something going to bring about an investigation. There is another thing we can do: and it could be HUGE if the snowball can grow into an avalanche, and that is this: STOP shopping at AMZN and spread your business to retailers that hire many people, and are part of local communities,etc.

If the stock manipulation has hurt you, don't buy anything from Amazon. More importantly, encourage anyone you know that might be long Amazon to sell the stock while the scam is alive. Let others hold the risk. Let's have retail get out at the top for a change. If you really feel that way, write an email and send to your friends and family. Explain to them what happened today and make sure they understand that the markets have become a game of simply trying to prey upon people rather than actually allocating capital to productive uses (else Apple would have gone up and Amazon down). Encourage them to pass it along... If people are smart, they will aggressively pull capital from the market. Invest locally in people and businesses you know and trust. Invest in physical assets that cannot be controlled and manipulated by co-located servers having a structural information advantage over you. I hope all of those that were hurt by this move (long or short) literally take the time to educate those around you. The markets have ceased to provide any value. The only times that the stock market truly creates value is with financings (IPOs, secondary offerings, acquisitions). The rest is simply redistribution from the general investing public to those that have rigged the game. You are much better off putting your money into local physical assets and gold for that matter (and yes, the physical kind that you control and that the HFT bots cannot take from you in a stop loss sweep). The point is this. Markets respond to signals. When the institutions see people pulling funds aggressively, they will get the message and probably not before then...

Topic.Title: Here's what's going to happen.

Message.Msg: Apple *is* getting more competition, but they can hold their own for several years, and dividends will carry them forward steadily. What the HFTs seem to be saying is that (for example) Amazon's foray into Apple's space with the Kindle will make them money, when in fact Amazon is starting from a competitive disadvantage (cost-wise, product-wise, popularity-wise), while eroding both their margins and Apple's. It's true that Kindle is different from ipad, etc., but the same rules apply: Apple had a first-mover advantage in integrating SSDs, screen over-production from TV flat-screen booms, and other miniaturized components, and thus got themselves a huge margin and initial sales. More competition is here now, and no one's margins cannot go up; Apple took a breather because of this fact. Somehow, the "buyers" of AMZN seem to think otherwise, but a reckoning is coming.

Topic.Title: I could not believe you are supporting Amazon Corporate officers and Board of Directors.

Message.Msg: California, one of the biggest state is beginning to charge sales tax in September along with a host of other states. If that doesn't cut down commerce, I don't know what is. I believe this is one of the critical competitive edge that they just lost to physical retailers. That's why they have been fighting so hard for many years with corporate trickery and loopholes to prevent this. But states are broke and starting to want their fair share of tax revenue. They've been using the revenue growth for years to keep even the smartest bull to ignore the puny little profit (now loses) they have generated. But revenue is useless if you have no profit. That's actually make things worse because, you're holding market share that eventually will be contested over. At some point, like now or the near future, revenue growth will not be possible but the operating losses are here to stay and growing. Than insolvency will be looming in the back ground. The retail "race to the bottom" is not good for many companies in general and Amazon is no exception. It leave them standing like a house of card, with razor thin margin and dwindling cash. Good luck withstanding another economic storm with the house of card like Amazon. I believe that the street is starting to wake up to the fact that the party is over for Amazon.

Topic.Title: I could not believe you are supporting Amazon Corporate officers and Board of Directors.

Message.Msg: I do not believe many (or ANY!) individual investors hold Amazon stock. It's the pension fund owners getting shafted by institutional buyers who collectively want to keep this ponzi scheme of a stock going, lest the bottom drop out. When the panic comes, though, it WILL drop out.
